beer-game-info.title: What is the Beer Game?
beer-game-info.body: The Beer Distribution Game was developed at MIT in the 1960s and has become a cornerstone of MBA and executive education worldwide. This supply chain simulation challenges players to minimize total costs while managing inventory and avoiding stockouts across four interconnected roles. The game demonstrates how information delays and limited visibility create the famous "Bullwhip Effect" - where small changes in customer demand amplify into wild swings upstream. Learn about its origins at MIT.

explanations.title: The Bullwhip Effect
explanations.text: Customer demand stays remarkably stable - just a small step change from 8 to 12 units, then back to 8. This is the only real input to the system.

explanations.title: The Retailer Response
explanations.text: The Retailer sees customer demand and tries to maintain inventory. Notice how their orders already show more variability than actual customer demand.

explanations.title: The Wholesaler Amplifies
explanations.text: The Wholesaler faces amplified demand from the Retailer and adds their own forecasting errors. Orders become even more volatile.

explanations.title: The Factory Chaos
explanations.text: By the time demand signals reach the Factory, they're completely distorted. Small customer changes create massive production swings - from 28 units to 0!

explanations.title: The Complete Bullwhip Effect
explanations.text: This is the bullwhip effect: stable customer demand creates chaos upstream. Each player acts rationally but lacks information, amplifying variability at every step.

aiq.title: What happens when AI plays the Beer Game?
